generalfeedback.text:
We aim to evaluate the integral \(\displaystyle \int_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S}\) where \(\underline{F} = ({@x^aa + y^bb@})\underline{i} + (x^2 + z^2)\underline{j} + {@cc@}xz\underline{k}\) and \(S\) is the square bounded by \((1, 0, 1)\), \((1, 0, -1)\), \((-1, 0, -1)\) and \((-1, 0, 1)\).

We first aim to find the vector \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S}\). As the square is in the \(x-z\) plane, we know that \(\underline{\hat{n}} = \underline{j}\), so we have \(\underline{\mathrm{d}S} =\underline{j} \mathrm{d}x\mathrm{d}z\). We can then easily determine the outer bounds to be \(z=1\) as an upper bound, and \(z=-1\) as a lower bound. The inner bounds are \(x=1\) and \(x=-1\) for upper and lower bounds respectively. We can now evaluate the integral as follows: \[ \begin{aligned} \int_S \underline{F} \cdot \underline{\mathrm{d}S} &= \int^{z=1}_{z=-1} \int^{x=1}_{x=-1} \left[(({@x^aa + y^bb@})\underline{i} + (x^2 + z^2)\underline{j} + {@cc@}xz\underline{k}) \cdot \underline{j} \right]\ \mathrm{d}x\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \int^{z=1}_{z=-1} \int^{x=1}_{x=-1} {@expression@}\ \mathrm{d}x\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \int^{z=1}_{z=-1} \left[{@First_int_indef@}\right]^{x=1}_{x=-1}\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \int^{z=1}_{z=-1} {@First_int_def@}\ \mathrm{d}z\\ &= \left[{@Second_int_indef@}\right]^{z=1}_{z=-1}\\ &= {@Second_int_def@} \end{aligned} \]
